column8: The oldest church in Halle. Closed both evening and afternoon...
column11: In fact, the name of this oldest church Halle, as in most Dutch cities, is still Groote Kerk=- Big Church. It may not be too big by Dutch standards. But there's less money in the colonies and less flock. Groote Kerk was built in 1755 on the site of a Portuguese Capuchin monastery. The foundations were laid 70 years earlier at the highest point in Halle, 12 metres above sea level. Centuries later, the high location and walls of the fort saved the church from the devastating tsunami of 2004. Interestingly, the freestanding bell tower is older than the church itself, as it was built in 1701 and was given to it by its predecessor church.  Unlike the Anglican -All Saints church, Groote Kerk did not get us. It was closed on both visits to Halle. Evening and afternoon. I suspect this is her permanent state...

Lovely little church situated within the Galle Fort. It was interesting to read the names on the gravestones and the various tablets erected inside. No entry fees were charged, but there is a box for voluntary donations near the pulpit.
Beautiful church made in 1755 situated inside Galle fort. It is a Protestant church. One should visit if he visits Galle.
In the fort, this Dutch Reformed church is one of the places with historical value. Next to the church is a small cemetery with tombstones from a distant past.
Amazing history, we paid for a guide to provide historical information. The inside is so interesting and you can take photos. You will be asked for a donation upon leaving.
There are several churches in Galle city and this is really interesting to see. But don‚Äôt limit yourself to this church, go for a walk and see them all so you understand the history of the city.

column8: Groote Kerk: one of the oldest Protestant churches in Ceylon
column11: Strange as it may sound, today there are almost no traces of its Portuguese founders left on the 36.4 hectares of land occupied by the Sri Lankan fort of Galle. I suppose you remember that in 1589 it was the descendants of the subjects of Henry the Navigator (Henrique o Navegador) who built the first fortification in Galle - the fortress of Santa Cruz Fortaleza (with earthen ramparts, bastions and wooden fortifications). However, in March 1640, an expeditionary force under the command of Commodore Willem Jacobson Coster, after a fierce battle, took the fort by storm and Halle became Dutch for many years. The warriors of the ‚Äúland of tulips,‚Äù taught by the sad experience of the Portuguese, by 1663 erected a monumental granite fort in Galle. The latter is included in the UNESCO heritage list as the largest surviving fort in Asia built by Europeans. In doing so, the Dutch incorporated the Portuguese north wall into a large rampart. The first (so-called old) gate to the fort was located next to the harbour. They are still there, marked with a heraldic bas-relief and the numbers ‚Äú1668‚Äù (as I understand, the year they - the gate - were erected). And not far from these very oude poort in 1775, the Groote Kerk (aka Dutch Reformed Church, also known as the Dutch Reformed Church) was built - one of the oldest Protestant churches in Ceylon. According to researchers, this temple was erected on the site of an earlier Portuguese monastery, Ordo Fratrum Minorum Capuccinorum (however, I did not find any reliable data about the latter, so I treat this information with great doubt). I am not good at the architecture of Dutch churches specifically from the period of colonial rule in Ceylon, but I can say that all the religious buildings of the Dutch (and, according to my calculations, there seem to be only five of them left on the island) are not similar to the various churches of Catholicism that I have previously seen, Orthodoxy and Protestantism. Not to mention other, less numerous ‚Äúbranches‚Äù of the Christian faith. And all the Dutch churches of Ceylon: Groote Kerk in Galle, Wolvendaalse Kerk in Colombo, St Peter's Kerk in Kalpitiya, Nederlands Hervormde kerk in Matara Fort, Kruys Kerk in Jaffna Fort - they are different and, at the same time, somewhat similar. The current Dutch temple in Halle was built with the care of the fort commander Casparus de Jong and his wife Geertruida Adriana Le Grand. In 1755, the latter happily gave birth to a long-awaited child (a girl) and, as a sign of gratitude to the Almighty for such a gift, Lord and Lady Spanbrook sponsored the construction of a temple on the territory of Fort Galle. Yes, to make it clear: the current church is definitely not the first Christian temple in the fort: the Dutch knocked the Portuguese out of the fortress in 1640 and, being zealous Christians, could not live without the sacred. Therefore, I agree with the opinion of researchers that the first Dutch temple appeared in Halle in the middle of the 17th century (it is documented that baptisms were already carried out in the Gallic church in 1678). As for the current Groote Kerk, we know exactly when this temple ‚Äúbegan working.‚Äù And all thanks to the daughter of Commander de Jonga: by decision of the parents, their daughter was not baptized until the church was built. And the corresponding entry in the church book indicates the date of the baby‚Äôs baptism - August 24, 1755!!! A couple of ‚Äústrokes‚Äù for the architecture of the sacral. In its spatial-volumetric composition it is close to Kolombov's Wolvendaalse Kerk; it has the same cruciform shape, only its transepts are much shorter. Retaining the weight of the floor was achieved through the original use of the structure of two large Dutch gables on the north and south sides. The pediments are originally decorated with pilasters, cornices, fancy stucco moldings, including volute-shaped, spiral shapes, and are completed with three finials resembling torches. The Groote Kerk in Fort Galle is a most interesting historical and architectural site. Highly recommend!!!

The Dutch Reformed Church or Groote Kerk is one of the oldest Protestant churches to serve this island. It was built by the Dutch in 1755 on the highest point within the fort, with its base standing more than 12 metres above sea level.
A small, rough church. Inside, the floor is paved with gravestones. Previously there was a monastery here, and the tombstones are from it. Gloomy.

The Groote Kerk or Dutch Reformed is located within theGalle Forte, and is near the entrance to the Fort.. The church was built by the Dutch in 1755 and is one of the oldest Protestant churches still in use in Sri Lanka

Did a walking tour of the Galle Fort Area and visited the church during the tour. A historical church building with a lot of history and cool to see all the inscriptions on the floor of the church in Dutch. It is free to enter. We did a quick tour of the place but definitely worth visiting if you are in the area.

This is  the nicest church I saw in my month long trip to india/sri lanka. The stain glass is just beautiful,  nothing ornate like a catholic church, its very simple, I just worshipped and spoke with the caretaker. Like other reviews please give a donation. Once again really nice church.

The DRC in the Galle Fort is an oasis of calm in the midst of The Forts hustle and bustle. It's a museum, a place of records, a historical building and an active place of Worship, all in one. Don't forget to make a donation for its upkeep - places like this need high maintenance and every bit helps.

This is situated in the galle dutch fort and it was built by the Dutch in 1755 and is one of the oldest Protestant churches still in use in the country. There are many tombstones stones date goes back the 18th century during the Dutch period. And also there were some 2 basement cellars, which were closed/ barricaded.
Peaceful church right in the centre of Galle. Definitely recommend anyone visiting Galle to make time to visit.
Well maintained little church. Lots if history. Don't rush a visit drink it in. Catacombs and secret passages, now blocked.
A very nice building. Not large, not ornate, although with some stained glass windows, an organ in the upper level and just a very peaceful ambience about the place.
See the tombs inside the church and the interesting churchyard with its cemetery. It takes you back the early days of Dutch colonial times.
Nothing spectacular, but the church is part of a series of colonial buildings from the Dutch era. Enough to stroll outside to experience the post-colonial vibe.
This is a pleasant historic church located in the town centre. It is worth visiting and walking round.
It's no great shakes unless you are into the history massively. Interesting design - no supports. Bit of a non event compared to the Buddha stuff around Sri Lanka

One of those things you see while in Galle, the church is surprisingly well kept, and is full of tombstones inside and out. There is also a small crypt that is locked. (Don‚Äôt fall down!) Stop. Look around. Take a photo. Move on. (And leave a donation.)
Stunning interior and a fascinating history make this a must see stop on any tour of Galle.  We were pushed for time but so glad we were able to have some time here.
Visited as part of whistle stop Galle visit. Nice enough, lovely history and beautiful views. Worth a visit
Well worth a visit to the dutch reformed church, very interesting tomb stones within the church, dated back to the 1600's

Built by the Dutch in 1755, it is still in use. Its foundation was laid in 1682 but never finished at that time. It was open when I visited. It is on, aptly enough, Church Street, near the Amangalla Hotel. It was built on the highest point of land within the fort, over the remains of a Portuguese Capuchin convent. Many grave markers line the interior floor. A walk along the exterior walls leads to many grave markers.
In one of the main streets of the town and drop in out of the heat to see an attractive little church
The church looks quite nice, definitely worth a quick stop. Its not very spectacular. The church was closed during our visit

The Church was built by the Dutch in 1755 on the site of a former Portuguese convent and is one of the oldest Protestant churches in Sri Lanka. It is a simple structure, cruciform in shape with arches separating the transepts from the nave. Interesting that Dutch gables support the roof. Nice stained glass windows and wooden pulpit with canopy over. Although the church was fully renovated in 2004, work is ongoing and workmen were busy cleaning the walls and pillars at the entry steps. The old cemetery is worth a look, it contains the reinterred remains of earlier Dutch settlers and their gravestones. A number of gravestones are also embedded in the church floor, you need to understand the Dutch language to decipher the inscriptions.

History covers the walls and floors of this historic church, which is liberally covered with highly decorative, beautifully carved stone tablets commemorating the early European settlers. The church is unfortunately a little run down but that does not detract from the charm and beauty of the historic building.

Located inside the Galle Fort premises. Its a very old church with a perfect antique constructed facade. Though not well maintained. There is a cemetery also, I presume, touching the church building. Not sure about this, see my snaps. There were some 2 basement cellars, which were closed/ barricaded. Nothing much to talk about.

This was the first site I visited in Galle and where I started the circuit of 3-4 hours with my driver waiting for me at the departing point. The most interesting part of the Church is the interior where you can see a lot of tombs as well as other religious art. The majority of the inscriptions is in Dutch.
Old church, interesting in that it shows something of the Dutch history of the nation. Very close to good shopping.

This church is ancient and, whilst having had some renovation, it could (like many churches) do with some work.  Having said that it contains some interesting features such as organ, pulpit and stained glass, and tombs

Because of the many grave markers both within and outside the church, this gives a sobering perspective on early western settlers in Sri Lanka - most deaths before age 40 and many younger than that.  Interesting to learn something about the earlier Dutch and British ex-pats.

After St. Peter's in Colombo, this is the second oldest church in Sri Lanka.  Spartan inside, it does have the tombstones of many dutch settlers and an interesting coat of arms on the wall.  Free, but they like donations.

This Dutch style Protestant Church was built in the eighteenth century and has been used by the Dutch and the British. It is still used today. There are many memorials and gravestones of people who died in Galle. Each of them tell a story.

This dutch place of worship is still preserved for visitors to see how the dutch lived.  the church still bears  the names of the dutch colonists, and the many tombstones bear witness to the long period of dutch colonisation.  Hope it will be preserved for the next generations to see

This church can be seen from walking around the fort, it is fairly dark inside. , but it is free to enter. The architecture typifies the era in which it was built. It is ok but nothing special but worth a look.
It was amazing to see all the old tombstones in the churchyard from so long ago.  And then to see tombstones on the floor of the church.  Quite unusual.  Lovely old church.

Came across the church when walking around the fort. Very small but clearly with lots of colonial history. Surprisingly cool inside with a few stained glass windows but not a lot else to see. The gardens have a few interesting items to look at but all in all don‚Äôt make a special trip to come here.

Perhaps we're lucky coming from the UK and having some of the nicest churches in the world? Perhaps also, that we're lucky that we've travelled a lot of Asia and seen churches in many other countries? Neverthless, on an aesthetic value only, this church is nothing impressive. Don't get me wrong, if you're here for purely historic reasons (or you have a passionate guide who knows the complete history of the building) it might be exactly what you're looking for. If you're here to look at a nice church (organ, pulpit, pews etc.) then you'll be done in about 2 minutes. Summary - an old church - it may be full of history, but it severely lacks in beauty or memorableness.

Fort area dotted with such beautiful architecture this definitely one of them. The placing of this place inside the fort makes it so different. The garden and the building kept so well that it deserves an appreciation for the Sri lankan.

Other than an overly enthusiastic caretaker inviting us to sign the visitors book and make donation this was an intersting place, particularly as a Methodist  Minister. It was fascinating seeing where some of the early Methodist missionaries had preached.
As is the custom  with this type of church, it was very simple, no gaudy trinkets but with some history

Like all churches in the tropics the high ceilings kept cool by the fans offers a lovely place to sit quietly and rest.  The walled gardens has some interesting headstones offering an insight into Galle's rich Dutch history.
This is a small church dating from 1755. There are grave markers in the church. There is an old baptismal dress framed on the wall.
Fascinating visit  given it's history. Worth a brief visit to examine the heritage. The Churchyard is worth checking out to.
very pretty church, not big but a niuce place to visit for 15-20 minutes. soak up and practice your Dutch with some tough names on the memorials,

This is an old church, and very simple as you'd expect for Dutch Reformed / Methodist etc. It's been kept up decently throughout it's life (maintained rather than renovated) and is interesting in that the floor is covered with old gravestones. The dancing skeletal "Deaths" are great. The caretaker was pleasant and offered to show us around as well

Walking around Galle Fort don‚Äôt go past this church without a quick look. It warrants a photo or two from the outside and a brief look around inside. The floor is amazing consisting of headstones from the graveyard.

A small, quaint church with simple plain artistry, I was fortunate to visit here just before closing time.  It was very quiet and peaceful and definitely gives you a sense of the colonial history in the area.
There is not much. This is a reasonably big structure. A few stained glass (not so great). It is like many of the churches seen elsewhere.
A small but beautiful church located inside galle fort. Suggest you to visit on Sunday during prayer time.
An old small church build but Dutch during colonial times in galle. I suggest to visit on Sunday during noon.

The Dutch church was a center for their colony, and the building is remarkably well preserved.   Well worth visiting.    I also enjoyed the All Saints Church, just nearby, and the Meera Mosque.     Old Galle was quite a good mix of people and cultures!
It is a church inside the fort area. Calm and good for prayer. Photos you can take inside. Visit if you are in Galle
An interesting historic property well cared for, well presented and open for all to enjoy. It is good to see how the Dutch worshiped when in charge of Galle.
This has been built by the Dutch when they were ruling down south. It is very old and must visit place if you want to study Sri Lankan history

We enjoyed stepping into this church while in the old town fortress area.  It was cool & calm & the architecture is typical traditional Dutch.  There's a real sense of history here & the place is very well maintained

Our visit to the Dutch Reformed Church was a very enjoyable experience. Love the architecture especially the arched roof. The stained glass windows were unique. The old flagstone gravestones on the floor were intriguing to read. A very nice church overall and worth a look.

In good condition and a good starting point as we entered the Galle Fortifications. Some real history in the writings on the tombstones in the floor of the  church and the church still functions today.

The Church is a marvel, preserved all these years. It was dedicated by the Dutch in August, in the year 1755. The interiors have been beautifully preserved all these years. The alter and the pulpit have been well maintained in spite of the years. In the flooring you will find the carvings and writings of the crypts of the earlier members. The surrounding lawns have also been well preserved. Tombstones of the Dutch are placed on the compound walls to commemorate them. There is an old pipe organ, which the Vicar said is still operational. The stained glass behind the alter is wonderful. Services in English, Sinhalese & Tamil are conducted. Not a place to be missed, it reeks of History and nostalgia.

This is a very well preserved and beautiful Church with a huge number of tombstones with detailed carvings and texts on the floor throughout. A peaceful place for quiet reflection upon part of the Colonial history of this town. A 'must' visit and do take your time.
One of the oldest church in Sri Lanka..seemed was built way back in 1640.. You can see some very lovely old artifacts ....

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. At our first visit at the fort we walked by the reformed church. In building style totally different than any church in the Netherlands, but in plan and function the same. Of great interest are the thombstones on the floor of the church with old Dutch-language texts on the colonists: what their function was and their age... They died so young! There must be people buried from our hometown Middelburg (one of the VOC-cities in the Golden Age), but we could only manage to find a woman from Vlissingen (6km. from our hometown). All in all a must see when you visit the fortress of Galle.

Beautiful church; inside perfecly maintained. As a Dutchman, it is a special experience to see a real historic Dutch church on this tropical island. The old tombstones in the floor with the epitaphs in the old Dutch language, the pulpit; it's really a piece of the Netherlands abroad and a perfect example of the history of the VOC (Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie).

Our tour guide brought us here and then allowed the parish priest to give us a little tour of the church.  It was incredibly interesting to learn about the early Dutch settlers and their families. Not sure if it would mean much if you don't learn about the history of the Church. We thoroughly enjoyed it.

Nicely restored church building. Especially interesting are old gravestones moved towards this church in the 19th century when two graveyards were closed. Enscriptions are easily understood by native Dutch speakers. Would be nice to have some English translations available for other visitors. Note the grave monument on the left wall (looking from the entrance), with a white child shirt: the Dutch owner, Abraham Samlant, commander of Galle, is supposed to have worn it when he was baptised.

Frustratingly we had to come back several times on our day in Galle before we could finally find this church open. It's a beautiful old church with a fine, imposing white facade right in the heart of Galle Fort. The inside is huge and serene with a typically understated and austere Dutch Reformed decor. Loved the smell of old wood and the dark pews. Some very venerable old tombstones inset into the floor make for interesting reading.
rich on history. Equipped me with first hand information as educator of history.Feel more sure with content delivery in lessons.Will recommend it as an iconic visiting place
Very interesting beautiful stained glass windows Historical worth visiting along with other things in the area

The Dutch Reform Church is a small building, quite busy with tourists. A short entrance from the street and facing is a long coloured glass window with a simple interior. It is an old Dutch church with beautiful architecture especially the tombstones placed on the church inner floor which make worth a visit while in Galle fort area. This church is one of the landmarks in the Galle fort which has retained the Dutch Architecture and very well maintained. Not really a lot to see here, but still worth taking a quick look, just to get the feel. Memorial stones on the floor make for interesting reading... We really liked the architecture of this church and it is well worth a short visit, if only to see the tombs and feel the peaceful atmosphere. However, we feel that the exterior needs some work quite quickly to avoid further deterioration. It is interesting to see an old Dutch church within the walls of Galle Fort. Well preserved. Worth a quick visit while walking around Galle Fort area. Located in an historical place the beautiful old church contain so much history! Incredibly preserved Church from the Dutch era it is right out of a Vermeer and you shouldn't miss seeing it. This was quite an interesting church. There were graves with the headstones that made up the floor, and a little cemetery found at the back. There were also some tunnels, but not much information. The colonials certainly left their mark at this church too.  For the historians it is an interesting place to visit.
This place seems very well aged and is well worth a look. It gives an idea of churches of the past with their relatively simple interiors.
The place is too good with a historic feel. Reminds of a small European town with a maintained church.
Fun old church still with a Dutch feel. The gravestone floor and wall slabs make for historic reading. Needing donations to keep it water proof do help them.

column7: Bay of Plenty Region, New Zealand
column11: nearly  three hundred year old amazing ,  oldest headstone we saw was 1716  now thats a long time ago  we were given an imprompt  tour around the church which was interesting

The church is old and no longer, I believe, Dutch Reform but for all that it is fascinating and the grave stones inside are worth spending some time over as they are often very clear and tell amazing stories of those buried below. And it has a certain calm.
Worth a few clicks and a visit with the inscription in Latin/Dutch. One of the first few monunments you see

On our recent visit to Galle we wanted to visit this church as it was were our Mum and Dad were married in1933. As a child prior to migrating I was taken to church and when I sat in the pew where mum and dad sat it was like I never left. The history of this church is shown by the head stones forming the floor, the christening garments from days past and many other items. If you are interested in the Dutch history of Ceylon a visit to this church and Galle fort is a must.

This Dutch Reformed Church (known as "Groote Kerk") was completed in 1755 and is a magnificent tribute to Dutch architecture in Sri Lanka. This white building is one of the best in Galle Fort but sadly its religious significance has been lost by the tramping of thousands of tourists in its hallowed walls, just wanting to take photos and selfies. The floor of the church is made up of intricately carved gravestones which people stomp on without any thought. That's a pity, but is a reflection of the millions of thoughtless tourists that wander our planet

This is a lovely building and the gravestones, both inside and out, are interesting. So many people died at a young age. If you are doing a self guided tour, such as the one in the Lonely Planet guidebook, then definitely go inside, and think about life here when the church was built.
Great place to stop and see memorial stones with family crests. Do the research before the time to appreciate the historical value.

The challenges of the first visitors and builders here are stark and reflected in this chamber . Not a must do here . Take a picture from outside. Like most other museo here it‚Äôs best just to wander and see what‚Äôs what. Way more clues on the outside of the architecture here than having to suffer hot interiors for little gains
If visiting the area then pop in for a look, nicely maintained and looked after. Nice architecture and very tranquil. A few gravestones to look at. Nice wooden pulpit.

As you enter the church the first thing you see are the  large grave stones on the foor dating back to the 1700's and earlier. The next thing I noticed was the blue painted wooden vaulted roof. The inside walls are painted white and at the rear is quite a magnificent wooden pulpit. It is a small church and is worth the visit if you are in town.
A quick look into the Dutch Architecture. Was fascinated by the way it is preserved. Peaceful environment with gravestones on the sides.Worth a look if you are at Galle fort.

A living church, showing the simplicity of colonial Dutch architecture, containing fascinating gravestones of worshippers from as early as the seventeenth century. The organ and pulpit are interesting. Please leave a donation to help this building survive as a local congregation must struggle with the upkeep of such a large church.

The Church is really nice conserved. The graves on the floor with their Dutch named and birth- and death dates bring you back centuries ago when our e struggled to live their lives far away from home in a time that the fastest communication still took months at the least. There is no entrance fee but a contribution to the maintenancr of the Church is well appreciated.
This was located in old town of galle the place itself is very beautiful and so is this church , the architecture was and history of the church was interesting
Get the custodian to give you a quick tour if you can. He has a great knowledge of the history of this building

This was a peaceful spot. A well conserved Dutch church with a friendly and informative curator on-site. We enjoyed sitting both in the church itself and outside, such a calming, peaceful location with lots of historical value.

Architecturally simple, this church gives a real sense of history through the memorial plaques to Dutch and English settlers, which cover its interior, and which tell a moving story, bringing the fort back to life.

As a Dutch citizin impressed by the history of the many gravestones. The church conservator told us a lot of the backgrounds. To the contrary of the other forts we visited this belongs to the one you should visit. A time als to relax from the heat in this time of the year.

This is a 10 minute look around . Free entry and the most interesting thing is to read the tombstones and memorials inside the church which give an indication of how fragile life was in the 19th century.
The church has been restored with care and thought. Fascinating gravestones and memorial plaques commemorating tough times.
This is a lovely church and through all the memorials you get a real sense of the European presence in Galle.
The church is fairly plain inside but has a nice blue roof, some unusual old wood features plus all the graves in the floor. Worth looking around for a bit.
This is very old church and it's beautiful inside .The old architecture is beautiful. You will not miss on your walk around here.

Stepping in out of the heat was a welcome break, well preserved  church, the floor inscriptions were what caught my eye, also with the light streaming through the stain glass windows.worth popping in.
Really old well preserved church and within walking distance of Galle fort and with restaurants and snack bars and parking nearby.
The church is large, nice etc. It was also open durung the day, unlikely the dutch church in Matara.
The interior is very plain, as one would expect from this denomination. There are some stained glass windows, but they are very ordinary. At least the place provides some shade.

Very nice historic building remaining from the Dutch colonial era. The white fa√ßade is an eye-catcher while walking along Church-Street. If you have the chance to step inside then you should have a look. It‚Äôs a bit dark inside and or European tourists the interior may not be something new, but it‚Äôs still interesting. The building is surrounded by a small lawn with some gravestones. /Ted
Well located to visit on a walk around the town is the historic Dutch Reform Church.Inside it is simple but has a few interesting historic features.
We stopped by and looked at the many gravestones inlayed to the floors and walls. Enjoyed the cool brake from the hot stroll around the fort.

The church is beautiful and in great condition. We spent about 10 or 15 minutes having a quick look around, especially at the tombs built into the floor. The writing, of course wasn‚Äôt in English but we could read the dates and some were adorned with a skull and cross bones. There were also tombstones of settlers outside the church, many of whom had died at a young age. You are sure to walk past the church so pop in for a quick visit.

Visit this old church for sure and be kind to leave some money in the till for its maintenance. The church is small and offers interesting stories if you get a chance to meet the caretaker. Keep an eye out for the skull and crossbones carved on the tombs.
Unfortunately the church was unattended so we were able to see inside but not able to talk to the current priest
A good visual display of dutch culture and Heritage, particularly the gravestones set in the floor of the church

Originally built by the Dutch and then taken over by the English there is a mixture of English and Dutch in the place.  Interesting to look at the stone on the floor which are Dutch and then take in the English ones scattered about the place

Popped in here as part of a day trip to Galle. Some very interesting features highlighting the lives (and deaths!) of the people who came her to colonise the town. Definitely worth a visit as part of a day trip/day visit.

This is a historic site, as you enter you get harassed to by bracelets etc. There are groups (Indian, not sure?) who seemed to see it as a cafe to sit in a chat loudly. No respect shown at all. If there was a usher in the church telling people to be quiet then things would be better. However the cacophony of animated voices ruins what could be a wonderful cool place to sit and read the history. STAFF needed to keep the noise down.

The only thing that makes this church worthwhile is that it is old. Am not sure if this place has a history though as we couldn't find anything written anywhere or anyone who could explain the significance of this place. Looked like any other church from the outside as well as the inside.
at this church you can see an old pipe organ along with century old pews and other church related artifacts
Churches sometimes are worth just poking your nose in quickly and taking it on on general without a great indulgent observation. This is one of those.

This church is worth a visit especially when you are from Dutch origin. It‚Äôs interesting to see the memorialstones, all written in Dutch. And that in such a tropical environment. The caretaker of the church is very kind and helpfull. It‚Äôs voluntary to donate.
The church is full of history take your time and  reflect on the nature of this church remember that you are in a holy place.Don't forget to make a donation if you want to take any pictures

A very old good kept church, as if it is straight from the history books of the old colonial times. It has a high historic value. No beggars or people asking for money, just a small sign that it is possible to donate a gift. A must see stop when going on a Galle Fort tour!
An ol church that you can visit as you walk in the old town. The day I was here there was a wedding rehearsal in progress, so was nice to see parts of this too here.

Though the church was going through renovation when we visited, it was still nice to wander inside and read the obituaries especially on the tiles and walls of the church of the people who loved or died there. The seating was still the original and the whole place had a peaceful vibe.

ƒ∞t is asmall church made by the Dutch.The church was under restoration when we went to Galle in august 2017. We visited the interior and took a lot of pictures.It was guite interesting having graves with headstones embedded in the floor and walls.

Tuesday 6th October and we took the local bus from our Hotel, Riu Sri Lanka in Ahungalla,¬† to Galle, it took about 1 hour journey and cost 60 SR Rupees, about 30p, each, single fare. While walking around the Fort in Galle, we came across this Church, it was just down the road, on Church Street¬†from the bigger and taller Church, All Saints Anglican, currently being refurbished. Despite being the smaller of the 2 Churches it had its own grace and charm outside. However the interior of the Church was rather minimalistic with the main features being a large stained glass window and the back of the Church, very high wooden ceiling painted blue and the gravestones on the floor. There is a wooden pulpit a small organ and at the back of the Church is a balcony. A person at the church informed us that the stained glass window was installed in 1830 by the British. The church was built in 1755 by the Dutch and is the second largest Protestant Church in the Country after the one in Colombo. It is still is use for worship. The Church survived unscathed during the Tsunami of 2004. Steeped in history well worth a walk around the Church and grounds. Take care when walking around inside the Church, the ground is uneven due to the various shapes and sizes of the gravestones. The Dutch Reformed Church (now the Christian Reformed Church) is one of the oldest Protestant churches still in use in Sri Lanka and  can be found in Galle Fort at the junction of Church Street and Middle Street and is easily accessed from the ramparts if you are taking in a circuit of the town wall, being at one of the points where you have to leave the wall itself temporarily and continue along one of the roads below it. It has the architecture typical of a large colonial church and is open to the public, the entrance being obvious and located on Church Street facing the rampart, though the belfry is curiously detached and stands across the road. The building you can see today was erected in the 1750s and as you enter you will notice the rows of seats, the gravestones on the floor and the organ up to the left. The organ was installed a little later in 1760 (there is a smaller 20th century organ) and on the far side of the rail separating it from the rest of the church interior there was a visitors book and a box for donations. When we called in visitors were being politely asked to make a donation for the running of the church but there was no pressure to do so and no suggested amount. It's nice to think if you can drop a few rupees at least into the box that you are helping both the local community through helping with the upkeep of the church and also doing a little to protect and maintain one of Galle Forts visitor attractions. It's also worth taking a few moments to notice the pulpit rather than just walk by. This was made with some pride by a craftsman using Calamander wood brought all the way from Malaysia. The stained glass window on the West side (the rampart is to the East) is a rather later addition, dating from 1830 The main feature of the church though lies mainly beneath your feet. Wander around taking in some of the many gravestones most of which were apparently originally in the Dutch cemetery before being removed to the church for their protection. There are memorials at various points around the walls too that are worthy of note and in some cases it's revealing to note the cause of death where mentioned and the ages of those who were interred. Sri Lanka may now be a holiday destination but for the Dutch colonists it seems to have been an unforgiving environment that frequently brought disease, sickness and a shortened life. We were told the oldest of the gravestones dates from 1662 but because of language differences we could ask little more. A number of the gravestones were also covered by chairs so it wasn't possible to view those towards the centre especially. There is a memorial on the wall near the pulpit to the De Ly family that produced one of the last Dutch governors of Galle, Andreas de Ly. As the last of his line he apparently stipulated in his will that his family coat of arms should be carried to his funeral and destroyed. There was no objection to the taking of photographs and lighting, especially for a digital camera was adequate so also respecting the fact that this is a place of prayer for many I did not use a flash. The Church was open between the hours of 9am and 5pm when we visited it in April 2015. Unless you have a specific interest in the church or its architecture or want to spend some time looking around the various gravestones a visit of 20 minutes or so should be enough to take in a little of the atmosphere and main features. If you are close by it is worth stopping in to see it if only because it gives a little insight into the Dutch colonists who gave Galle Fort so much of its character in terms of the wall, buildings and general layout and something of the British who followed them; a number of memorials recording the end of those who had also served in India or were making their way home. It is also very much on the route if you are following the line of the rampart on a walk. I hope you enjoy it.

A beautiful piece of living history in the centre of Galle fort. Interesting to see the graves that date back to the 1600s

I wouldn't recommend coming to Galle for this church but it is a quaint and interesting building that is fascinating in the history it holds. Definitely worth a visit if in Galle. We really enjoyed walking through it and reading the memorials on the walls.

Probably more interesting if you have Dutch roots. This small church brings you back to the old days, of small community and hardship. Most folks in the graves did not get very old. Wander around the church and look at the stones, and if you read Dutch this makes interesting history.
It's really old and holy,the beauding is so nice. I like holy place, if you stay here, you will feel like near God.

This former Dutch and now Christian Reformed Church seemed to be better maintained than its famous Colombo counterpart. Reading the tombstones in the nave was instructive. Hiwever overall Protestant churches have an emptiness about them compared with Catholic Churches.  This is no exception.  The Protestant ones lack a sense of the sacred.

Certain Sri Lankans tend to assume that people resembling them by  looks could be treated rudely and disrespectful. Any person irrespective of where you from and what you look like should be treated with respect. I had several experiences being treated badly.

Stepping in to the Dutch Reform Church in Galle Fort provides an opportunity to see the history written on the tombstones in the garden and the memorial stones inside the Church. Much insight provided to illustrate the bygone days. Very well maintained structure with an interested curator on hand to answer questions.

Being a C of E man myself I am used to long naves but this one drew me in with its 'inclusive' atmosphere.  Dutch Reformed has a rather severe image - fundamentalist protestant type - but here the feeling was - laid back almost. This is not a major feature of the Fort area but worth a look. Its a worth visit that you might never seen a similar church like that anywhere else.  Photography is allowed and donate maybe 1 USD for admission.    A great generation of tombstones, some dated back to around 16th Century

The Church is simple and silled with tombstones, on the floor and on the walls. It is a fuss- free church and th Pastor is happy to show you around. The aftrnoon light made the jewelled satin glass windows gleam. The old organ is beyond repair. But the chirch still has service. As you walk over the floor stones, you see generations of history, from the Dutch to the British , so many lives have been here, prayed here, lived lives in Galle and died here. A small donation is not too much to make, and I did so happily.
This is a beautiful church with an old history. I love the old setting inside and the floor which is paved with gravestone is amazing.

this is not an ornate church the tombs and memorial stones tell a tragic tale of young lives cut short by the tropical conditions without the benefit of modern medicine. lifespans are often given not only in years and months but also days. Quite moving

We would recommend this small church as one of the key attractions to see when visiting the Fort of Galle area. Dating from the 18th Century but with much restoration this church holds a key to much of the ecclesiastical and social history of the town.  It is usually open for visitors and it is worth making a donation to acquire a guide to explain the history and artefacts. The church is immaculately clean and well kept and is a beautifully calm and peaceful place to spend some quality time out of the heat of the outdoors.
It is fairly new compared to the rest of the city.  It was interesting to see all the tombstones and imagine what life would have been like for them
if I was planning a wedding, this church would be in one of my top places to consider. It makes you feel special.

This was one of the highlights of our trip to the old town - at least it was open to visitors unlike the Anglican Church! A very smart church with much history - Dutch tombstones cover the floor and many British memorial plaques adorn the walls. I was slightly irritated to be actively 'encouraged' to make a donation, but hopefully it does all go to maintaining the church.

This is a must see - it is so superbly kept the bench seats, the organ,  the pulpit you are stepping back in time - probably one of the best examples in the sub continent - certainly that I have come across - a real treasure
Went here on our tour of Galle . Very interesting building and kept really well. Our guide showed us all the history of this church. Well worth a visit.

As you drive around the fort your eye catches this small Dutch church standing for ages as testimony to the religious leanings of the community that lived inside th fort city of Galle.   White washed walls stands in sharp contrast to the blue skies.  The iron gate invites you into the premises kept immaculately clean, a place to sit and meditate enveloped by the quietness.   A beautiful place to spend sometime reliving an era gone by.
I liked - the history and looking at the people who had lived in the area and had been buried there.
1 metre thick walls provide a nice cool place to take in some history and sit and contemplate. Courtyard has graves going back centuries.

Not far from the fort to this lovely peaceful church ...very helpful staff and younare left in peace to enjoy the moment , dont forget to sign the book and put a  donation ... it goes a long way to the upkeep of it..makes me feel good too..
If you like old churches then this is your place but other than a quick photo shoot then time to move on.

Worth looking inside; a pretty historical Dutch church with floors laid with the gravestones of former Dutch citizens. The church apparently dates back to 1755. Very atmospheric.  Tablets laid in the walls also record the lives and deaths of the later British settlers. No entrance fee but they do like you to sign the visitors book and leave a voluntary donation. Allow 15 minutes to see it.
Read the tombstones and take guesses at the history of the people and families in the colonial times. Don't miss to go to the left side outside the church.
Fascinating snapshot of life under the Dutch and English inside and around the old Church. We found names of soldiers and trading families who could even be related to us.

Interesting visit that showed the Dutch influence on this part of Sri Lanka. One of the church members was there and without being overbearing gave us some interesting information on the church's history
On our tour of the Fort stopped to visit the church. Lots of people inside and it contained lots of memorials   A very interesting visit

Nicely curated and clean. Outside is surrounded by cemetery and inside you can see the tombs. A lot of nice woodwork to see even a wooden place to preach. A must visit if you are visiting the Galle Fort. Its nearer(walking) to the clock tower side entry. There is maritime museum further from the church. Have a nice one!
A beautiful church inside the Galle fort. A lot of history behind this church. Lot of architecture and beauty in this church.
An easy visit while in fort area. Interesting church, no fee to enter, only donation required. Part of Galle fort near to new gate entry (cricket stadium side).

So the most glaring thing about the church is presence of tomb stones on the floor of the church. Many of them have a skull sign which is quite unseen before (for me at-least). Somebody in the church told me that it signifies birth (mostly of a royal family child) due to disease. Clearly there is quite a bit of history here.

The church has been built for over 300 years and undergone many changes during the past years under foreign occupation.  The mosaic windows were beautiful while the many tombstones with scripts laid on the floor of the church were particularly interesting.  Really worth to visit and is easily accessible in Galle Fort area.
It's amazing visiting this place. There is a graveyard on the right and you will find some old clothing and accessories used by 18th century Dutch.

Really small, but mystical Church. Inside plenty of  tombstones people which lived here 300 years ago... came fro Holland and try to build here. Church is really small, worth of see. In my opinion one of best "old European" monument in Sri Lanka

This building is close to entrance of Galle. It is small and very historic. The mosaic windows are beautiful as in most churches. It was eerie to walk on floors which were actually tombs. You can grasp some history by reading the epitaphs. Attracts a lot of people so the "quietly sitting" does not happen!

We took a 50Rp bus from Ambalangoda (1hr10m) to visit Galle. The church is traditional 18th century Dutch in white enclosed with a wall and having a graveyard to the right. It also has 2 underground crypt entrances in the graveyard. A wealth of features, nice pulpit, coloured glass windows and gravestones built in to the floors. I understand the Dutch govt. paid for its recent refurbishment. There is a guest book and donations accepted. Great Place!
An easy visit while in fort area. Interesting but not stunning. No fee, only donation required. Some gravestones in courtyard area.

If you're planning to visit Galle Fort, this wonderful old building, quite close to the entrance to the fort is an absolute must. You can trace the changeover from Dutch to English through the moving memorials - well worth a visit.
An excellent legacy to the founding fathers of Galle. The minister was friendly and  informative and pointed out some of the unusual headstones which were laid into the floor..

The old world charm of the church takes you back in time. Also stepping into the cool shade of the cavernous vestibule from the scorching sun is quite a relief. Another stop after visiting the church should be the Galle Fort library. Mr.Abeywickrama the amiable librarian is very welcoming & informative despite the board saying "members only".

Having walked around the Galle Fort, our driver took us to the Dutch Reform Church, which is also situated within the Galle Fort area. The Dutch Reform Church was built nearly 250 to 300 years ago and is significant landmark visited by many tourists. The church we were told had undergone several major changes during the British occupation and a fair amount of restoration has been carried out more recently. The building is very well maintained and I thought was a charming piece of architecture. It is a very important part of Sri Lankan history, highlighting the influence European occupation has had on the island.
Well worth a visit and if you are lucky the priest will give you a guided tour... gives you an insight to the Dutch history of the area

Without a doubt, this is an important part of historical fabric of Galle.  It is rather well-maintained inside and out, and from look of things, almost all tour groups come here.  You get to see graves of people who are buried within its compound and headstones being used as part of floor inside the Church.  What I love about the Church is seeing humanity that's humming outside especially when the school finished in late afternoon.
Well maintained Church with a vast amount of history to back up. Worth the watch & dont forget to have a peek at the exit hideouts.

If you have any interest in history and the lives (and deaths) of those gone before, this is a fascinating church. It reflects the history of Galle fort, housing Dutch and British tombs alongside each other inside and outside the church, which is charming and very well kept.

I've been to Dutch reformed church located in Colombo place called Wolfandhall in the biginning of my tour.. it is pretty interesting to see it again at gale. end of this week i will be in gale for 3days and I should visit. thnx for sharing.

History everywhere, when in Galle, this is a MUST-SEE. One gets to see the history and feel it too, the is definitely the highlight of my Galle's visit. Make a small donation, say 50 rs. Wander around and marvel at the interior, and the courtyard full of stone tablets of deceased Dutch residents who lived in Galle. All in all, a place I can highly recommend.
Worth visiting.... can see a church during the Dutch period at its best....  also you can see where the prisoners have been held captive in the past

I really enjoyed visiting the early dutch church. While it was very old it had a feeling of being cared for. I was really taken with the gothic imagery on the relief carving high up on the left as you walk in. Church stained glass windows always entrigue me and I enjoyed these. There was a nice feeling of space inside and was very peaceful . Well worth a visit.
as Dutch man its great to see such an old dutch church preserved so well in Galle fort which is also Dutch. Very interesting place.

I wouldn't make a special trip here but it's worth looking in as you pass. As a previous reviewer has said, it is beautifully cool inside.  That might not sound interesting in the UK in March but last week in Galle it was really important!  The stained glass is wonderfully understated.

this church has a nice clean exterior so it looks as though its taken care of, and its worth a look in. it simply designed like many Asian churches but this adds to its appeal, it is interesting reading the headstones inside the church and using for quite contemplation or to get out of the hot sun.
Lovely service and singing underway on the Sunday of visit. Fascinating old memorials with tragic history of many early deaths. Lovely exterior, and quiet cool inside.

The church is totally of Dutch architecture and it maintains it's architecture and the Dutch tradition well. Also there are graves if important Dutch personnel buried inside the church. There are also passages outside the church that lead to the docks etc.

This is perhaps the first stop when you enter Galle fort from the Cricket stadium entry. It is a peaceful and well maintained church with one big room. There are numerous gravestones on the floor. If you are in the fort it is worth a visit

We visited the church prior to the Sunday morning Service in Sinhala which unfortunately owing to time constraints we were not able to attend. I wished that I could read the writing on most of the gravestones and the thought of all the young lives lost before their prime (on those I could read) was saddening. I could almost envision the place in days gone by - all those generations of worshipers - trusting in GOD - to see them through, in their lives in an alien country so far from home. Being half a Burgher myself all those "Brohiers, Van Twests, etc" long gone - meant I spent a lot of time at each and every memorial stone. This place is full of atmosphere.
The gravestones and architecture of this historical church are very interesting...a good glimpse of the Dutch presence and history.
Once you came to the Galle Fort you must bring a visit to the Dutch church and take a look inside. It's well preserved and restored.

This old Dutch church basically consists of one big airy room without much decor. The peaceful atmosphere and the feeling of centuries gone by makes a visit here worth it, though. The numerous gravestones in the floor are also fascinating. The local helper who talks to you all the time and asks for money to the restauration of the church is a major annoyance. Give us a moment of peace, man!

Looks great from the main road. If you walk around the side you will notice that the other sides have not had the same restoration or care. This is a shame, as it brings the whole experience down a notch. Still worth a visit though.
Quite interesting woodwork and architecture. Pity that churchkeeper is a bit annoying. She follows you around as if you will put something in your pocket. Her begging for money really annoyed me.

De Nederlands Hervormde kerk, Galle  was build in August 1755.You can see the Church intact  even today .Though not maintained  verywell yet it stands testimony of its time and is a wonderful piece of architecture built by the Dutch.

After spending a couple of hours sightseeing around Galle on Tuesday 20/08/13 my excellent taxi driver suggested I take a look inside the old Dutch Church, I'm so glad i took his advise !!! A most enjoyable visit & spent 45 min's taking in the amazing history & relaxed peaceful atmosphere, spent 10 min's walking outside & reading the head stones, a great location & worth visiting. All donations to the church are appreciated.

A historical church and def a must see in Galle. The grounds inside & outside are full of gravestones. Just reading all the names & dates on the gravestone would given you an idea on the history of the ppl who lived and died in Galle. May be a little morbid to some but in a historical sense, it's very interesting. The interior of the church is very old, wt an organ and a pulpit. It's not a very large church but very interesting. The caretaker of the church was very helpful in giving a little bit of background and history behind this church. Worth visiting .

The church is filled with gravestones and graves, and sometimes you are actually walking on top of them which is kind of Morbid. The architecture is nice. There is a caretaker who yo ucan ask questions, its a so so place if you are in to gravestones!
Visit the church both inside and out to view centuries old gravestones, some with skull and cross-bone insignias.

If you love colonial places like Malacca, etc., you'll really enjoy visiting this Dutch Reformed Church.  Its remarkable how well it's preserved, considering it's pretty much in open air in a tropical environment.  There are so many interesting tombstones, the original organ, pulpit and even crypts out back.  We were really delighted to visit here--definitely make a trip if you are in Galle.

You may not be a normal church visitor but this is worth a visit. See the organ, the lay out of the church but most of all take some time and read the inscriptions from Holland and England and glance into the short lives of the colonial settlers. The memorial to the four year old so lovingly done, the grand tombs of Dutch knights and the sad memorials to young women dying in the 20s. Very evocative

The floor is amazing, history at your feet. This church is so well preserved and still in use as a place of whorship. The couple who look after it are always pleased to see visitors and do a great job of day today upkeep.
Awesome old church.  Spend some time reading the tomb stones inside, those reflect the lives of the people back then.

A lot of fuss made over a church really. There is a lot of historic buildings in Galle and this is just one of them. It felt weird walking over graves within the church but it does have a lovely old pipe organ.

This is such a nice place to go to. I have been there quite a few times, when I was small. However, during the most recent trip to Galle, I could not go there due to the lack of time. There is a saying among the villagers that this place is haunted. There is a large church organ inside this very old church. My grandfather has showed me an opening to a tunnel from the garden of the church and he said that it is now caved in. Unfortunately, I have forgotten what he said it was for. There are tombs inside the church and there is something very gloomy and mysterious about the place. This is therefore, well worth visiting. The architecture of the building is worth noting.
Visiting just in time... several couples very making their wedding photo, so there was a lot to see... Interesting feeling to be in a church in a tropical country.
Well worth a visit. Seeping with history and conjures thoughts of another time and place... was also lucky enough to witness a wedding, which was a real treat!

A must see building when in Galle  ,to put the history of the place in context .In side the architecture is typical Dutch reformed ,very interesting .Outside the grave yard is informative giving information of the congregation deaths .
This was most interesting church to visit steeped in history. with a very informative guide.  It is well worth a visit.
The history of the Galle Fort is interesting and the Dutch Church is should be seen in this context but it is not remarkable.

Went here as its one of the first attractions inside the new main gate of Galle Fort, and felt somewhat uplifted inside. Its run-down, and yeah you get asked to put donations in if you want to take photos, but the history inside is worth it.
The Dutch reformed church is situated within the fort. The interior is interesting and the tombstones tell the long history of the church and the lives of the early settlors.
It's certainly worth popping in whilst you're in town, but there is nothing really special to see inside the church.
Travel back in time inside this gorgeous church. Even non-believers get goosebumps when reflecting on the history.  A must visit.

It makes you realise how far our ancestors travelled to make their fortune; what must they have felt so far from home and what must the local people have thought of them? The church was so European set in this wonderful fort.
Very old church 1755 original crypts, pews, organ and many other items make this church a must see in the city of Galle.
This sweet small church will give you an overview of the Dutch history in Galle. The gravestones on the floor has the most interesting texts!

This was interesting from the point of view of Sri Lankan history, but just another reminder of the evils of colonization and the heavy role religion has always played. It's not an impressive church by any standards, but if you're there, it's worth a visit. It's free with requested donations

The friendly caretaker made all the difference to our visit to the Dutch Reformed Church. He is genuinely passionate about the place and knows all the details which he freely shares, especially if you show interest. What a relief too to find a place with genuine local hospitality, and not just a place owned by foreigners and then staffed by locals.

I visited this church firstly to hide away from the glaring sun of Galle Fort. It was an unusual experience. I very nice gentlemen explained to me not only the colonial history of Galle but also the fate of the people finding their last rest.
This is a terrific bit of European history in Sri Lanka: a quaint church with tombstones that reveal the island's turbulent past and much more.

not like in other churches, this one has a keeper that seems to be there most of the time ... gave briefs to the visitors about its history and cleaning the church as well. nothing much to see but remembrance of the people who died in that era

Built in 1640, the church is next to Amangalle Hotel. It was built at the highest point in Galle by donations from a Dutch army officer as thanks giving for the birth of his daughter. Her tiny baptism dress and other items are on display on one of the walls within. The church floor is paved with grave stones and the walls outside are lined with memory stones.  The old organ is as old as the church! There is an elderly gentleman who is available on site to explain the history to visitors. He seemed to expect a "tip". I would think Rs.100 would suffice. On the side of the church is an underground passage which some say was used by the Governor during the war. This tunnel connects to his house which is diagonally across the road. Some say it leads to a Burial Chamber. The church is well preserved and deserves a casual visit, if not during the service.
